content:
To get around in Sardinia, you can use a combination of transportation options, including flying, trains, buses, and driving, which offer a range of choices for travelers with different budgets and preferences. 

[FACTBOX]
Main International Airport(s): Olbia Costa Smeralda Airport (OLB), Cagliari Elmas Airport (CAG), Alghero-Fertilia Airport (AHO)
Domestic Air Network: moderate
Rail Network: limited
Drives On: right
Road Quality: good
Ride-Hailing Apps: local alternatives
[/FACTBOX]

[SECTION] Getting There [/SECTION]
Sardinia has three main international airports: Olbia Costa Smeralda Airport, Cagliari Elmas Airport, and Alghero-Fertilia Airport, which receive direct flights from major European cities, including Rome, Milan, and London. The island is also connected to the Italian mainland by ferry services from ports such as Civitavecchia, Naples, and Genoa, offering an alternative entry point for those who prefer to travel by sea. 

The main airports in Sardinia are well-connected to the rest of the island, with shuttle bus services and car rental options available. Overland entry points are limited, as Sardinia is an island, but there are several ferry terminals that connect the island to the mainland and other nearby islands. The most popular ferry routes are from Civitavecchia to Olbia and from Naples to Cagliari, which are operated by companies such as Tirrenia di Navigazione and Grimaldi Lines.

[SECTION] Domestic Flights [/SECTION]
Sardinia has a moderate domestic air network, with flights connecting the main airports on the island. The main domestic airline is Alitalia, which operates flights from Olbia, Cagliari, and Alghero to other Italian cities. Booking in advance is recommended, especially during peak season, as prices can be high. Approximate costs for domestic flights in Sardinia range from 50 to 200 EUR, depending on the route and time of year. It's also worth considering budget airlines, such as Ryanair, which operate flights to Sardinia from other European cities.

[SECTION] Trains & Rail [/SECTION]
Sardinia has a limited rail network, with trains connecting the main cities on the island. The main rail line runs from Cagliari to Sassari, with stops in Oristano and other smaller towns. The trains are operated by Trenitalia, which offers a relatively efficient service, although not as frequent as in other parts of Italy. There are no high-speed trains in Sardinia, but the scenic routes offer a pleasant way to see the island's countryside. Booking can be done online or at the train station, and prices are relatively affordable, with a one-way ticket from Cagliari to Sassari costing around 10-20 EUR.

[SECTION] Buses & Coaches [/SECTION]
Sardinia has an extensive network of intercity buses, which connect the main cities and towns on the island. The main bus companies are ARST and FdS, which operate frequent services throughout the day. The buses are comfortable and relatively affordable, with prices ranging from 5-20 EUR for a one-way ticket, depending on the route. It's worth noting that bus services can be limited in rural areas, so it's a good idea to plan ahead and book in advance.

[SECTION] Driving [/SECTION]
- To drive in Sardinia, you need a valid driving license from your home country or an International Driving Permit.
- The road quality in Sardinia is generally good, with well-maintained highways and scenic coastal routes.
- Fuel costs are relatively high in Sardinia, with prices ranging from 1.50-2.00 EUR per liter.
- Car rental companies are available at the main airports and in major cities, with prices starting from around 40 EUR per day.
- Hazards to watch out for include narrow roads, steep cliffs, and limited parking in urban areas.
- It's a good idea to rent a car with a GPS system, as signposting can be limited in rural areas.

[SECTION] Transport Tips [/SECTION]
- Be aware of scams, such as overpriced taxi fares or fake parking attendants, and always agree on a price before starting your journey.
- Payment methods in Sardinia include cash, credit cards, and mobile payments, but it's always a good idea to have some cash with you.
- Download the **Trenitalia** app to book train tickets and check schedules in advance.
- Consider purchasing a **Sardinia Tourist Card**, which offers discounts and free entry to many attractions.
- Be mindful of **summer traffic**, especially on the coastal roads, and plan your itinerary accordingly.
- Don't drink and drive, as **road safety** is a priority in Sardinia, and penalties for drunk driving are severe.
- Take your time and enjoy the scenic routes, as **driving in Sardinia** can be a pleasure, with stunning landscapes and picturesque villages to discover.
